5.verification_summary: Mathematical derivation shows that for p being a normal density with sigma and w being a normal density with alpha times sigma, w(x) equals 1 over alpha times p(x) to the power 1 over alpha squared, i.e., w(x) proportional to p(x)^(1/alpha^2) with a prefactor 1 over (alpha times sqrt two pi times sigma).

7.verification_summary: Based on standard probabilistic estimation and finite sample noise, absolute error for low probability events can be small while relative error is large, implying greater relative uncertainty for rarer events.
